channel.title: Commands

item.title: Commands
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

[quote=“zyle1992, post:15, topic:410877”][quote author=_s link=topic=512139.msg3726018#msg3726018 date=1314278333]

Possibly use a HashMap<String, Player> instead of cycling through every player online every time the command is executed.

Also, you don’t break out of the for-loop anywhere. It might be a small thing, but why continue to compare players if the code shouldn’t possibly be executed again.

Most of your lookups are playerId based, therefor that method is very faulty - I suggest having a hashMap of playerName, playerId instead.

What lookups?

edit: woh, it’s late

For example PvP combat sends the playerId of the player that is being attacked.

But having a HashMap<String, Player> makes more sense than <String, Integer>. By doing the former, you are interacting with the Player object itself. You could simply add an “entityId” variable to the Player & Npc classes (or a common super class if you have one). That way you can do

final Player player = World.getPlayers().get(username);
final int playerId = player.getId();
final Location loc = player.getLocation();

instead of doing

final int playerId = playerIds.get(name);
final Location loc = playerLocations.get(name);

And you could use _s’s (I believe) system for available indices.

t4’s system*

ps HashMap<Integer, Player>
[/quote]

Oh, I thought he said that it was based on your design.

Anyways, why would you prefer a HashMap<Integer, Player> over a HashMap<String, Player>? Since most commands are referenced via player name (ie. much easier to do “::kick zyle1992” than “::kick 248”), it would be much easier to add an “entityId” field to the player/npc class. Or is there something I’m missing?[/quote]packets deal in player ids and not player names, you’d be best off keeping two reverse lookup tables

Read full topic

item.title: Commands
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

[quote=“baddy351, post:16, topic:410877”][quote author=ExtremeX-Scape™ link=topic=512139.msg3719522#msg3719522 date=1313853082]
you have a empty string at the end of your c2.sendMessage(""); string.
[/quote]
Do you really hate empty strings? You also point them out xD.[/quote]

Aside from them serving no purpose, I believe that it still allocates memory for the object.

Possibly use a HashMap<String, Player> instead of cycling through every player online every time the command is executed.

Also, you don’t break out of the for-loop anywhere. It might be a small thing, but why continue to compare players if the code shouldn’t possibly be executed again.

Most of your lookups are playerId based, therefor that method is very faulty - I suggest having a hashMap of playerName, playerId instead.

What lookups?

edit: woh, it’s late

For example PvP combat sends the playerId of the player that is being attacked.

But having a HashMap<String, Player> makes more sense than <String, Integer>. By doing the former, you are interacting with the Player object itself. You could simply add an “entityId” variable to the Player & Npc classes (or a common super class if you have one). That way you can do

final int playerId = player.getId();
final Location loc = player.getLocation();

instead of doing

final Location loc = playerLocations.get(name);

And you could use _s’s (I believe) system for available indices.
[/quote]

t4’s system*

ps HashMap<Integer, Player>[/quote]

Oh, I thought he said that it was based on your design.

Anyways, why would you prefer a HashMap<Integer, Player> over a HashMap<String, Player>? Since most commands are referenced via player name (ie. much easier to do “::kick zyle1992” than “::kick 248”), it would be much easier to add an “entityId” field to the player/npc class. item.title: Commands
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

lol2011:

No point optimizing commands, it really won’t make any difference at all, there’s so many other things that you could optimize on wL servers. If you’re so worried about performance and optimization, write a server from scratch or use a base of one that is written properly.

way to repeat what i said

Read full topic

item.title: Commands
item.dc:creator: @imsuperman05 imsuperman05
item.description:
@imsuperman05 wrote:

I’ve been looking over the commands, and i can’t tell if their efficient or not. So i need your opinion.
Which is better? I took a random command out.

if(playerCommand.startsWith("yunban")) { String[] args = playerCommand.split(" ", 2); for(int j = 0; j < Config.MAX_PLAYERS; j++) { if(PlayerHandler.players[j] != null) { if(PlayerHandler.players[j].playerName.equalsIgnoreCase(args[1])) { Client c2 = (Client)PlayerHandler.players[j]; c2.yellbanned = false; c2.sendMessage("You have been unbanned from yelling by: "+c.playerName+""); c.sendMessage("You have unbanned "+c2.playerName+" from yell."); } } } }

Or?

if(playerCommand.startsWith("yunban")) { String[] args = playerCommand.split(" ", 2); for(int j = 0; j < Config.MAX_PLAYERS; j++) { Client c2 = (Client)PlayerHandler.players[j]; if(c2 != null) { if(c2.playerName.equalsIgnoreCase(args[1])) { c2.yellbanned = false; c2.sendMessage("You have been unbanned from yelling by: "+c.playerName+""); c.sendMessage("You have unbanned "+c2.playerName+" from yell."); } } } }

Read full topic
